parse.title: List of statues of British royalty in London

text.*:
This list is incomplete; you can help by expanding it.
The equestrian statue of Charles I, Charing Cross

This is a list of statues of British royalty in London.

Contents

  • 1 House of Mercia
  • 2 House of Wessex
  • 3 House of Denmark
  • 4 House of Wessex – Restored
  • 5 House of Normandy
  • 6 House of Plantagenet
  • 7 House of Lancaster
  • 8 House of York
  • 9 House of Tudor
  • 10 House of Stuart
  • 11 House of Hanover
  • 12 House of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha
  • 13 House of Windsor
  • 14 See also
  • 15 References
  • 16 Bibliography

Image Title / subject Location and
coordinates 		Date Artist / designer Type Designation Notes

More images 		Edward VI St Thomas' Hospital 1682 Thomas Cartwright Grade II* [12]

More images 		Edward VI St Thomas' Hospital 1736 Peter Scheemakers Grade II* [13]

House of Stuart[edit]

Image Monarch / ruler commemorated Location Date Sculptor Notes Source
James I Temple Bar Gate, Paternoster Square c. 1670–2 John Bushnell
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1861–4 Thomas Thornycroft Intended for the Palace of Westminster. [16]
Anne of Denmark Temple Bar Gate, Paternoster Square c. 1670–2 John Bushnell
Charles I Charing Cross

51°30′26″N 0°07′40″W﻿ / ﻿51.50732°N 0.12770°W﻿ / 51.50732; -0.12770﻿ (Charles I)

1633 Hubert Le Sueur The earliest English equestrian statue. Originally commissioned in 1630 by Charles I's Lord Treasurer, Sir Richard Weston, for his house Mortlake Park in Roehampton. Erected on the site of the Charing Cross in 1674–5, when the pedestal was carved by Joshua Marshall. [17]
Temple Bar Gate, Paternoster Square c. 1670–2 John Bushnell
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1671 John Bushnell Intended for the Royal Exchange. [18]
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1861–4 Thomas Thornycroft Intended for the Palace of Westminster. [19]
Charles II Temple Bar Gate, Paternoster Square c. 1670–2 John Bushnell
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1671 John Bushnell [20]
Soho Square 1681 Caius Gabriel Cibber
Royal Exchange 1789–91 John Spiller [21]
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1865–71 Henry Weekes [22]
James II Trafalgar Square 1686 Peter Van Dievoet working in the studio of Grinling Gibbons [23]
William III St. James's Square 1807 John Bacon the Younger [24]
Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1862–7 Thomas Woolner [25]
Outside Kensington Palace 1908 Heinrich Baucke [26]
Mary II Central Criminal Court, Old Bailey 1862–8 Alexander Munro [27]
Anne Market House, Kingston upon Thames 1706 Francis Bird
Queen Anne's Gate, Westminster 1708 at latest Francis Bird
Maughan Library (King's College London), central tower 1866–7 Farmer & Brindley [3]
Outside the west front of St Paul's Cathedral 1886 Richard Claude Belt [28]
